response.answer_text: I once nearly drowned as a teenager. It’s a long story, but I wasn’t breathing when they pulled me out of the water, and I ended up in hospital. Funny thing was that I LOVED swimming. But after that episode, I sincerely disliked swimming. I was nervous in the water. I felt something was going to attack me from below… I was actually scared. Bear with me - this IS relevant to the question and to my answer to the question. A month later, I was at university, but swimming was still intensely anxiety-triggering. But I wasn’t having any of that anxiety bullshit. I enrolled in a scuba diving course and learned to dive in the snow, with an ancient wet suit full of holes and ancient equipment. It was horrible. But… I lost my anxiety. I started to enjoy the water again. And I ultimately ended up working as a scuba diving instructor (years later) for about 12 years… What is the point of my tale? “Writer’s Block” isn’t a thing. People use it as an excuse. It’s a lazy way out. “Oooh, I have writer’s block, so there isn’t any point in sitting down and writing… So I might as well goof off. But as anyone knows who is serious about writing knows, writing is really, really hard work. There will be days when the words flow almost on their own, and there will be days where you struggle for hours with a single sentence and feel useless and incapable. And here’s the trap: If you now convince yourself that you have some made-up mysterious ailment like “writer’s block”, then you will end up actually convincing yourself that you can’t write. And each time to try to do so anyway, you’ll ascribe failure to write productively to this “writer’s block”, which reinforces your conviction that you are useless. And this brings us back to the tale at the beginning of the answer. Don ’t let this anxiety, this “writer’s block” take control. I’m convinced that there is no such thing because I find it is not useful to believe that it is a real thing. My tactical approach to kicking the ass of “writer’s block” real or fake… is to sit down every single gorram day and write. No matter what. Write. If I think I have “writer’s block” or constipation of my creative flow… I still write. Because I’m not letting myself get in the way. Some days what you write will be shit. Shrug and move on. But keep at it. Don’t let your fear that you can’t write actually get a name and all. Just get out there and kick its ass. Like I did when I thought I’d never be able to swim and enjoy the experience again. I faced that fear and kicked its ass so thoroughly that it’s still looking for its bum thirty years later. Do the same for your writing, if you’re serious about writing as well as you possibly can. Don’t let some piddling worry that you can’t write get in your way. Get out there and show it that it’s wrong. Just do it, basically. Then this “writer’s block” thing has no more power over you. Just write.

I wouldn’t necessarily call it writer’s block. I look at it as an obstruction to write which can be caused by a number of things. We’ve come to a stopping point in our story There are times when I’m at my keyboard, or with a notebook and pen and I just can’t seem to write fast enough. I have so much to say, I’m excited and the words are just filling the pages. I type and type , the time whizzes by and then suddenly it comes to a halt. It’s like someone just turned off the switch. Some will refer to this as writers block. For me it’s just a stopping point in my writing. I’ve simply reached a point in my story that I need to sit back and think more about before putting pen to paper. When this happens, I don’t stare at the manuscript, frustrated and in despair, waiting for the words to begin to form again. No, I walk away. It’s time to regroup myself, refresh my mind and find other activities to do. I remove myself entirely from my writing activities. Sometimes a cup of tea will do the trick and I’ll return fifteen minutes later. Other times it maybe a few hours, but when I do return, my mind is fresh, I have new ideas and I’m anxious to write again. The key is to walk away and give your mind a break. You want to write but can’t come up with any ideas We are writers because we love to write, we love to create and we have many stories to tell. But sometimes our creative juices runs dry. This is when we need a little push to get us inspired again. There are so many methods one can use to ignite fresh ideas. Here are just a few: writing promptsPictures from magazinePhotographsLook out your window - Write about what you see and create a story from the scene .Newspaper and magazine articles.Your petsFinding that inspiration is just like writing. You need to be creative. Look around you, there are so many things to inspire a story. You can find more writing prompts on my website Weekly 7-day writing prompts Archives - Tina Hogan Grant Life gets in the way Another issue writers experience, is finding the time to write. As much as we want to write, our busy lives keeps getting in the way. Sometimes we can’t even find one hour out of our busy schedules to write. When this begins to happen we have to remind ourselves that our writing is just as important as those dishes that are calling us to be washed, or the grass that needs to be mowed. We need to get into the habit of putting time aside to write on a daily basis. If we don’t it can sometimes turn into days if not weeks before we attempt to write again. Periods like these can mistakingly be referred to writer’s block when it fact it’s your everyday life that is preventing you from writing. Knowing the reasoning for your lack of writing, it can be rectified pretty easily.

“Writers’ Block” (WB) is an affliction almost unknown among writers, something akin to farmers’ lung or housemaid’s knee. There are three forms of the affliction. By far the most common form, and the one most widely discussed here on Quora is a strange phenomenon. Thousands, perhaps millions, of people, who could not by any stretch of any imagination (apart those imaginations of other members of this group) be described fairly as “writers” discover that they have nothing to say and/or don’t know how to say it. These people are not writers, so cannot suffer from WB. They are simply people who say they are writers, yet they cannot even start, let alone complete, a work that anyone other than highly sympathetic friends or members of their family would want to read. These are the kind of people who suffer from altitude sickness walking up the hill to fetch a pail of water. This is not WB. This is just a combination of attention seeking behavior, laziness and an absence of talent. It’s very common. More than 99% of people suffer from it, but the symptoms do not become obvious until they decide to call themselves writers for no clear reason. That’s what most people on Quora are suffering from. Lack of ideas, energy, originality or talent. Little snowflakes. Then there are two forms suffered by people who “anyone” would describe as a writer, not just themselves and their support group. There is an answer somewhere by Andy Weir, author of The Martian, in response to one of the many question from those non-writers above asking how to cure their WB. He says, “Go for a walk.” This answer satisfies “real” writers completely, but lacks the depth and complexity necessary to satisfy those who are living in fantasy land, but who can’t write about it. You see, most things you think of as WB are just a combination of laziness, boredom and a lack of ideas. It’s not some magical Jungian affliction, though I think there is a Robertson Davies novel about a blocked writer seeking Jungian counselling, but that is the next group. You know when kids don’t want to school today, or when you don’t want to go to work? Coal miners block, first graders block. Almost all WB is nothing more than a lack of ideas, and frankly, it can only be suffered by “writers.” I almost never have any ideas, I almost never feel like writing, I am almost always too lazy to be bothered writing, just like most of the world and certainly most of the people above. It is the normal human condition. It only really matters for writers and people arrogant or stupid enough to call themselves writers. For a writer, it is only a problem when it starts to interfere with their income - and yes, that is the definition of a writer: a person for whom writing forms a substantial part of their income. The way to cure it is to go for a walk, get stoned, have drink, bake a cake, masturbate, watch a movie, go to the shooting/golf range, drive your car around the backroads,, have a nap, strangle a chicken. It’s not a “thing” any more than any other lack of enthusiasm for work is a thing. Then there is REAL WB. This is a medical condition, a psychosis, and it does not happen a lot, but it does happen. Some writers simply find themselves unable to write, even afraid to write and it is a bit like erectile disfunction (ED), the more you look at it, the worse it becomes. “Today, I’m going to get it up and give my missus the shag of her life,” is not a mindset that will cure ED , nor will pulling yourself together, no any of the other homespun remedies for mental illness. In short, WB, real WB, is a very rare psychological condition which affects a very small number of writers. It can be cured by therapy, it may just go away of its own accord or you may be stuck with it forever. It is not something you need to worry about before your third or fourth novel.

Writer’s block is not an equal opportunity affliction. Non-fiction writers rarely experience it. Their work depends on organizational skills and clear thinking. Both are pretty sturdy. Fiction writers are prone to writer’s block because their work depends on imagination and imagination is one of the by-products of self-confidence. When fiction writers experience diminished self confidence—they’re facing a writing problem they don’t know how to solve, ideas just aren’t coming to them, their inner editor tells them their idea or their work isn’t very good—they have trouble facing the blank screen or blank page. So, what’s the cure? Do things that increase your self-confidence, but don’t rely much on creativity. Do more research. You know you need to. Research provides you with the facts you need to make your book credible, but more than that, it sparks ideas. Work on your outline. Add details. Fill in the blanks. Deal with story holes. Excise the unbelievable. In other words, accomplish something—not the writing of text, but something else, something useful, something that will give you a feeling of accomplishment. That will raise your self-confidence. What should you do with the tiny amount of renewed self-confidence? Pick out the part of your book that is easiest for you to imagine. Write that. Go on to the next easiest, and the next easiest. In that way, by the time you confront the hard stuff, you will have a pile of pages beside you of completed or well-drafted work. Nothing is better for your self-confidence than accomplishment. This is not a one-time solution to the problem, by the way. You can use it whenever you run up against a stone wall. It will give you the self-confidence to bust through the wall the next time you try.

A writer’s block? It is a bogey everyone engaged in literary creativity dreads more than a highly infectious disease. It is a distressing condition in which the writer suddenly and inexplicably becomes incapable of the inspiration and the creative energy needed to form words out of thoughts with the style and elegance that fire up good prose. Another one of the writer's really bad times are those times when an event or subject he wants to write about, stubbornly defies coher­ent narration because all the facts are standing on their heads. I find myself confronted by both barri­ers from time to time. Take heart when the bogey strikes. Sooner than later, he departs, and you can go to work all over again.

There isn’t anything like WRITER’S BLOCK. For me, The Writer’s Block is a situation where the writer has become lazy. It isn’t anything related to null of thoughts/ ideas like that. But at certain times, a writer becomes lazy or depressed due to his/her personal conditions. Only Time Heals The Pain. If I could give some tips about overcoming the writer’s block, then here you go: Travel to some places you’ve never been to before. New things and new places always excites a person.Go for long walks. Walking results in talking with brain.Try reading a good, less paged book.Listen to music. I recommend Classic.Watch interviews of famous writers.Spend time with your family and friends.If possible try spending your time with little children.Visit a temple/church, any holy place. You’ll be surrounded with positive aura.Watch Movies.Try to forget the pain. Very important.

I think it is a mental mirage. Like any obstacle you can always get around it, over it, or under it if the will is in place. Writers will get obsessively stuck on a section of their book, paragraph, or even one word for hours, day and yes sometimes weeks on end. The idea is to redirect and pull your craft in another direction momentarily then come back to it. Think of it as your friendly GPS saying, “Rerouting.” Sitting in the same spot waiting for that highway repair blocking your way for construction workers to finish just does not make since. There is always a detour. It is the same with writing. Write on another project (we all have several in the works), write some poetry, hell even write a letter just keep that pen flowing to eliminate the mirage of writer’s block.

There are two voices in your head—one whispers in one ear and the other in the other ear. Voice one is called Writer. The other voice is called Editor. Block happens when Editor gets the upper hand over Writer. Writer writes and editor says, “That’s sure shit. Where did you ever come up with that load of crap?” Writer freezes as Editor keeps it up. The hand freezes. “Who are you fooling with that drivel?” Writer asserts control. Editor has no control over the pen, pencil, keyboard or tape recorder. Writer starts writing. “I am writing. My hand is moving. The keys are being hit. The writing process is happening.” Editor tries to throw you off, but you don’t fall for it. You keep going until you get tired of saying you are typing and then you start describing the room you are in and the next thing you know you are not blocked and for me, at least, I end up back in the story. And Quroa is great for expository writing about a random subject that catches your eye.

Writer's block is both a fictitious and a real phenomenon. It is fictitious for writers who neither suffer from it nor believe in it and real for those who do. In the most simplest of terms, a writer is said to be suffering from writer's block when they stare at a blank paper or screen and just blink. It is a period of utter dejection, loss of interest and loss of ideas. A writer is not able to write and enjoy their craft. Even if they do feel like writing, no words come to them. If the words do come, then the writer absolutely hates them because they make no sense, or the hand does not move to type or pen them. A writer's block is most commonly a manifestation of a burnout, loss of interest and priorities, fear, laziness and lack of a writing routine.

There is no such thing as “writer’s block.” What there is, is your subconscious objecting to what you have planned. Maybe your character is acting completely out of character. Maybe your plot twist is ridiculous. Maybe your romance is forced and contrived. Basically what you have planned for the book is wrong on some level or in some way, and your subconscious is putting a hold on things until you fix it. You need to sit your ass down in a chair and start trying to think of all the other things that could happen in the story from that point. You’ll know you’ve found a good one when you suddenly discover you have stopped asking questions and can’t wait to write it out.

I have two kids. Some days it’s awesome and we have a great time at the playground, at the park, reading books or building with blocks. Other days, we have time-outs, and a few too many harsh words and lots of complaining. No matter what the day holds, I’m still called to be a parent. That’s the way writing is to do. If you’re really a writer, you’re a writer everyday. No matter what. Some days are easier than others. But you’re still writing, creating and trying new ideas. Writer’s block is real, but that doesn’t mean you stop. Instead, you find a way around it. You take a break. You work on something else. You copy. For more writing tips, check out Create Make Write.

When I stop writing for few days or so then come back to my writing schedule it becomes very boring at this moments that I feel I’ve nothing to write. This block situations can be a huge stone on our career’s progress. You will need to get out of it ASAP and get back to your writing schedule to resume the progress and growth. Here I’m writing up about THREE PROVEN METHODS I used to use when I’m passing by such situations to get rid of what is called Writer’s Block as soon as possible.

"Writer's block" is what happens when a writer has run out of ideas or whose writing has brought him to a dead end.My journalism professor described "writer's block" as the luxury of would-be writers; writers who depend on their writing for their living can't afford to sit at their desk or event to put off writing until inspiration strikes ... they plow ahead, writing and re-writing and getting the work done.

Writer’s block refers to a short or prolonged period of inability to write. Some think of it as a psychological block in creativity, while there are plenty of professionals who laugh it off. To see writer’s block as a condition is wrong, the notion that is a psychological condition that applies only to writers isn’t factual. To see it as a period where professionals lack proper motivation is proper, as it is the case for everyone in their respectable careers.

Writer’s Block is a disease of the dilettante writer closely related to other imaginary afflictions and is said to make the mind blank as the patient tries to write. Here is the story I tell people who “have” writer’s block. As I first heard it, it was told by the songwriter and record company executive Johnny Mercer to the guitarist and staff writer Merle Travis: Your kitchen faucet leaks. You call the plumber. When he arrives he tells you he’s sorry, he can’t fix it today because he has Plumber’s Block. That doesn’t happen. If the plumber is having an off day, he fixes as best he can and if it doesn’t work, he comes back tomorrow and makes it right. You think you have writer’s block? So write anyway. If it’s a worthless piece of junk, fix it tomorrow morning.

Poets and writers often start writing on a variety of subjects, as and when they get some good idea or get inspired to write on that subject. While penning down in a systematic manner to proceed with that idea, development of thought process starts working ad continue to write and proceed with the subject. But sometimes, they lose track of their thought process or they find it difficult to write best / correct words to convey exactly the same meaning what they had originally planned in their thoughts to write. That situation or the point of thought process is called “Writer’s Block” , meaning thereby - that the writer finds it difficult to write really correct words to convey his thought process. And at that time, good writers leave the draft of their writings for a couple of days, give some rest to their brains, and when they come to know that correct words are coming to them just like leaves come to a tree or a plant, they again start writing and complete their works.

Sometimes I’ll sit down and a hundred ideas flood my mind. So many ideas; I can’t write them down fast enough. Other times, I struggle to grasp one coherent thought worthy of transcription. Every idea or topic is disjointed and fleeting and I can’t discern one scraggly thought, much less write about it. It’s beyond frustrating. This, my friend, is writers block.

It’s different things to different people. I experienced it after a bad road accident recently and it was: a) getting upset the ideas weren’t coming in the same wayb) comparing what I used to write with what I was writing after - very dissatisfiedc) starting to write, get to the half way point, and then abandoning the project. In short, I was very unhappy. I don’t know how but I’m more on track. I’ll be curious how other creators respond.
